docs.lead_paragraph: The first drug to treat fibromyalgia has been approved, but some dispute the very existence of the condition.

headline.sub: Some Doctors Dispute Existence of a Pain  ;

docs.snippet: The first drug to treat fibromyalgia has been approved, but some dispute the very existence of the condition.

docs.lead_paragraph: Fibromyalgia is a real disease. Or so says Pfizer in a new television advertising campaign for Lyrica, the first medicine approved to treat the pain condition, whose very existence is questioned by some doctors. For patient advocacy groups and doctors who specialize in fibromyalgia, the Lyrica approval is a milestone. They say they hope Lyrica and two other drugs that may be approved this year will legitimize fibromyalgia, just as Prozac brought depression into the mainstream.
docs.abstract: Food and Drug Administration's approval of Lyrica, developed by Pfizer to treat fibromyalgia, may help legitimize controversial condition, diagnosis that some doctors reject; fibromyalgia affects primarily middle-aged women and is characterized by chronic, widespread pain of unknown origin; its sufferers do not typically respond to conventional painkillers, so drug companies are focusing on medicines that affect brain and perception of pain; advocacy groups and doctors who treat fibromyalgia estimate 2 percent to 4 percent are afflicted, but figures are disputed by doctors who do not consider it recognized illness and who say that diagnosing condition worsens suffering by causing patients to obsess over aches that other people tolerate; they warn that Lyrica's side effects, which include severe weight gain, dizziness and edema, are real and dangerous; despite debate, American College of Rheumatology, FDA and insurers do recognize it as diagnosable disease; Eli Lilly and Forest Laboratories have asked FDA for permission to market drugs and approval appears likely by end of year; graph; photos (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Researchers at Harvard Medical School have identified 273 proteins that the AIDS virus needs to survive in human cells, which could lead to new strategies for combating the disease.
